evidences.pdf_reference:
Abstract
Photocatalytic conversion of CO 2 to chemical feedstocks represents an intriguing approach to address the energy and environmental crisis, but faces low conversion efficiencies resulted from unsatisfied light absorption, charge recombination and surface reactivity of traditional semiconductor photocatalysts.Herein, we report stacked graphene/PdPtCu nanostructures with atomically thin PtCu shell to overcome above challenges and realize high-efficient CO 2 -to-CH 4 photoreduction.The smart design begins with the excitation of Ru complex with broad visible absorption, which is followed by the smooth movement of photoelectrons via the graphenePdPtCu pathway, and then the highly selective CO 2 reduction on the PtCu surface.As the PtCu thickness decreases, the strengthened Pd-PtCu interfacial charge polarization contributes to improved charge separation/migration.Meanwhile, CO 2 adsorption on the PtCu surface is ameliorated owing to increased electron accumulation and compressive strain.This work provides a new design for boosting the photocatalytic performance by cooperative surface and interfacial modulations.
Experimental

evidences.pdf_reference:
Abstract
Photocatalytic conversion of CO 2 to chemical feedstocks represents an intriguing approach to address the energy and environmental crisis, but faces low conversion efficiencies resulted from unsatisfied light absorption, charge recombination and surface reactivity of traditional semiconductor photocatalysts.Herein, we report stacked graphene/PdPtCu nanostructures with atomically thin PtCu shell to overcome above challenges and realize high-efficient CO 2 -to-CH 4 photoreduction.The smart design begins with the excitation of Ru complex with broad visible absorption, which is followed by the smooth movement of photoelectrons via the graphenePdPtCu pathway, and then the highly selective CO 2 reduction on the PtCu surface.As the PtCu thickness decreases, the strengthened Pd-PtCu interfacial charge polarization contributes to improved charge separation/migration.Meanwhile, CO 2 adsorption on the PtCu surface is ameliorated owing to increased electron accumulation and compressive strain.This work provides a new design for boosting the photocatalytic performance by cooperative surface and interfacial modulations.
Experimental

evidences.pdf_reference:
Abstract
Photocatalytic conversion of CO 2 to chemical feedstocks represents an intriguing approach to address the energy and environmental crisis, but faces low conversion efficiencies resulted from unsatisfied light absorption, charge recombination and surface reactivity of traditional semiconductor photocatalysts.Herein, we report stacked graphene/PdPtCu nanostructures with atomically thin PtCu shell to overcome above challenges and realize high-efficient CO 2 -to-CH 4 photoreduction.The smart design begins with the excitation of Ru complex with broad visible absorption, which is followed by the smooth movement of photoelectrons via the graphenePdPtCu pathway, and then the highly selective CO 2 reduction on the PtCu surface.As the PtCu thickness decreases, the strengthened Pd-PtCu interfacial charge polarization contributes to improved charge separation/migration.Meanwhile, CO 2 adsorption on the PtCu surface is ameliorated owing to increased electron accumulation and compressive strain.This work provides a new design for boosting the photocatalytic performance by cooperative surface and interfacial modulations.
Experimental
